newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Police unearth bones in Belgian child sex scandal.
newsitem.headline: Police unearth bones in Belgian child sex scandal.

text.p: Belgian police found what appeared to be human bones on Tuesday while searching a property owned by Marc Dutroux, chief suspect in the country's paedophile abduction, pornography and murder scandal.

"We discovered bones, probably of a human nature," Gendarmerie spokesman Major Jean-Marie Boudin told reporters outside the house in the Charleroi suburb of Jumet that was formerly occupied by Dutroux associate Bernard Weinstein.
"They will be exhumed and taken for an autopsy this afternoon. The identification process will follow -- that will take some time, several days even if necessary," he added.
He refused to speculate on whether there could be more than one body.
Police have been digging in and around the house, one of six owned by Dutroux, for the past week. The bones were found in a shed in the garden.
Public Prosecutor Michel Bourlet, leading the hunt for a paedophile sex gang and its victims, was at the site as was police pathologist Jean-Pol Beauthiez and an ambulance.
Boudin urged the media not to speculate about the identity of the remains saying: "We don't know"
He said searches were suspended when the bones were found. It was not clear when they would resume.
The find follows discovery of the bodies of two eight-year-old children and that of Weinstein on August 17 at a house owned by Dutroux in Sars-La-Buissiere, south of Charleroi.
Dutroux, who admits murdering Weinstein, said the two children, Julie Lejeune and Melissa Russo, starved to death earlier this year, some nine months after being abducted
Two other girls, Laetitia Delhez and Sabine Dardenne, were rescued from another of Dutroux's houses 12 days ago.
Dutroux, a convicted child rapist, has admitted kidnapping at least two others, An Marchal and Eefje Lambrecks.
No human remains had been found previously at the house in Jumet.
